e4: I recommended maintaining the current policy with a slight bias rather than changing to a new policy without bias because it may disproportionately harm smaller, less sophisticated investors who are more likely to be caught off guard by a change. Their investing decisions and portfolio performance could suffer as a result of not being able to adjust their expectations for earnings. While the new policy aims to provide accurate financial information, I believe the potential risks to retail investors outweigh any benefits.
e5: I would view an ethical reporting policy as transparent, honest, and consistent. It should provide clear and accurate information that helps investors make informed decisions. A policy should also minimize harm to any group of stakeholders, particularly those who may be most vulnerable, such as retail investors. In this context, transparency and a clear understanding of the adjustments being made are crucial. For instance, if a company chooses not to adjust its reported earnings, it should clearly communicate this decision and provide evidence or justifications for why this choice was made.
e6: What plans are in place to ensure that retail investors can adjust their expectations for earnings under the new policy, and how will this be communicated to them? Additionally, what measures will be taken to prevent sophisticated hedge funds from trading on the assumption of a slight bias in reported earnings?
q9: C/2013 A4, also known as Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko, first detected in 2013, but this was a comet not an asteroid, its parent body (asteroid) 3200 Phaethon or 3200 Philae was later observed and first detected in 1999
